b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:21): it's still interesting what the preferred form of making modifications is

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:22): which is currently generated straight from the html5 source document

e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (10:23): you're creating HTML to RFC?
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (10:24): sweet, please make it a Web service

e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (10:41): I wonder how the content type sniffing goes down at the IETF
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:42): lisa's happy with having it, how the http wg will take it is another matter
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:42): of course i've no idea really where lisa fits into the politics of the ietf
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:42): i guess she's the equivalent of an activity lead at the w3c, who don't really have much power in practice
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (10:44): there are loads of conflicting specs at the IETF, surely?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:48): hrm. I need to figure out which stack node pointers in the AAA a strong and which weak...
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:48): that is, if a node is held once it has been removed from the stack
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (11:12): hixie: there is no HTTP WG, only HTTPbis, and our charter is very restrictive in what we can do
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:13): i was referring to the members of httpbis

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:13): incidentally, you often refer to the charter being restrictive as if that was some immutable law -- you do realise the charter is whatever the group wants it to be, right?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:14): it's restrictive because some people want it to be restrictive

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:15): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: do you remember off-hand if there are ever situations where the AAA holds an element locally without the element also being on the stack or the list of active formatting elements at the same moment?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:16): not off-hand
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:17): I'd rather not develop a memory management overkill on the C++ side for local variables if the stack and the list keep the objects alive anywoy
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:17): don't you run the algorithm all in one go?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:18): oh wait, gecko uses a ref counting mechanism
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:18): never mind
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:18): an autoreleasepool would rock, sure
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:19): or a real garbage collector
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (11:37): hixie: the charter is not what the WG members want, but what the IESG approved
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:37): what's the difference?
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (11:38): http://www.ietf.org/iesg.html
0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89 (11:38): Title: IESG (at www.ietf.org)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:38): no, i mean, what's the real difference?
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (11:38): It's a totally different group of people.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:38): if the IESG said that the HTTP working group charter was "turn HTTP into FTP", would the HTTP group o it?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:38): s/o/do/
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:39): even though they thought it was stupid?
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (11:39): No. But what does that prove?
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (11:39): Peope volunteer to do work in the WG.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:39): the IESG doesn't just make up charters
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (11:39): If they don't like the charter, they'll just not participate.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:39): they approve charters that will have participants
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (11:40): the charter doesn't have participants
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:40): if there had been a body of people who wanted to do HTTP 1.2, then that's what the charter would do
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:40): you know what i mean
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (11:40): I think you need to learn a bit more about the IETF :-)
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (11:41): If the proposal would have been to do HTTP/1.2, the likely outcome would have been that no WG would have been chartered.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:41): if people want to do something, they do it, charter or no charter
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:41): html5 being the most obvious example of that
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (11:42): But that doesn't mean that the IETF will participate in it.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:42): yeah, that's what the w3c thought about html5, too
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:56): In retrospect, the Atom WG should probably have defined a format on top of RSS despite the objections of Dave Winer instead of defining a new vocabulary.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:57): yeah
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (12:00): yeah, but the problem feed like formats solve are very simple so it does not matter much
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (12:00): although feed interoperability is still bad
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:03): e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0: I still see the RSS <title> problem every week approximately in NNW

e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (12:04): well yeah, interop is bad, processing of invalid feeds is not defined, processing of non well-formed XML is not defined, etc. but compared to stuff that can change dynamically and all it is still relatively simple
